thread.title: 'Amaizing' Tasmanian maize crop shaped into map of Tasmania maze
thread.title_full: 'Amaizing' Tasmanian maize crop shaped into map of Tasmania maze

author: Laurissa Smith
title: 'Amaizing' Tasmanian maize crop shaped into map of Tasmania maze
text:
Map: Hagley 7292 
A paddock of maize in Tasmania's north-east has taken on a life of its own. 
The three and a half hectare crop at Hagley has been carved into a maze in the shape of Tasmania. 
The 'amaizing' maze is the fourth on Rowan and Anna Clark's Rupertswood Farm. 
In the past their preferred crop has been sorghum but this year the pair planted forage maize to get more height. 
"It's probably around seven feet and I'm very pleased with the way it's gone because I've never grown maize itself," Mr Clark said. 
"I'd like to have it a little bit thicker, just for our purpose." Photo: The theme for the 2017 maze, grown of maize, is Tasmania. (Facebook: Rupertswood Farm) 
It took Mr Clark two days to shape the crop on a wide mower modified with a GPS guidance system and a bulker bag for sun protection. 
He said he included the small islands around the state in the maze, but admitted they were only a rough representation. 
"King Island is a big part of our children's mini-maze," he said. 
"I think there is a little bit of a bump around where Bruny [Island] is because some of the finer detail is hard with the mower because it's 6-feet wide. 
"A couple of the lakes are also a bit tricky, but hopefully I've mastered them." 
The Clarks, who farm sheep and vegetables, diversified into agritourism about four years ago and threw open the gates of their property to the public and enabling them to interact with farm life. 
The maze, designed by UK maze specialists Mazescape, is one of their more popular activities and will be open for most of March. 
It will then be mowed for silage. 
"This variety, I've been told, is more a forage variety and if it didn't get the units, it may not form a cob," Mr Clark said. 
"[That] has not concerned me at all because the logistics of having cobs and kids running around together ... it could lead to some awkwardness."
